Title: 10 Dark Supernatural Episodes You Need to Mentally Prepare For
Description:
Supernatural (2005-2020) is a fantasy horror show that ran for 15 Seasons and had over 325 Episodes. The early seasons of Supernatural were known for pitting Sam and Dean Winchester against ghosts, vampires, wendigos, and all things that go bump in the night. Eventually, demons and angels were introduced, upping the ante of the series as the Winchesters fought bigger and badder enemies. Some episodes, like Season 1, Episode 5, "Bloody Mary," were inspired by terrifying urban legends, while others elaborate on creatures from mythology.

Most fans can agree that Supernatural lost its "horror" edge after the first couple seasons. Season One through Season Four feature plenty of terrifying episodes that will keep fans up at night, but Supernatural lost some of that magic when it started focusing on bigger and more ambitious overarching plots. That said, Supernatural contains some exceptionally dark episodes that fans need to mentally prepare for before watching.

At the end of Season 5, Sam Winchester sacrifices himself to stop the apocalypse. He does this by allowing Lucifier to possess him and then jumping back into "the pit," a cage built specifically to house Lucifer. The Season 5 finale suggests Sam will be lost to Hell forever, but surprisingly, Sam returns from the pit almost immediately thanks to Castiel's help. Castiel, however, was not able to retrieve his soul. The first half of Season 6 focuses on Soulless Sam and his older brother, Dean, trying to figure out what's wrong with Sam.

Once Dean finally realizes that Sam is missing his soul, he makes a deal with Death, one of the Four Horsemen, to retrieve Sam's soul from Hell. This episode is dark because Adam, Sam and Dean's younger brother, is also trapped in the pit, but Dean saves Sam over Adam. Dean also agrees to Death's deal, where Dean has to become Death for a day. Dean spares a dying child, which results in several deaths that were never supposed to happen. This concept made a lot of viewers face the idea of fate and that they truly have no control over their lives and how they ultimately end.

The first few episodes of Season 10 focus on a continued plot from Season 9 where Dean possessed the Mark of Cain. With the mark still on him, the angel Metatron killed him, which resulted in Dean becoming a demon. Sam spends the first few episodes of Season 10 plotting a way to capture Dean and cure him of being a demon. In "Soul Survivor," Sam and Demon Dean stand-off, and some fans have compared the episode to Stephen King's The Shining, with Demon Dean taking the part of a possessed Jack Torrance.

Dean Winchester is one of Supernatural's most beloved characters, and there are more than a few reasons that prove why.

In this episode, Sam attempts to cure Dean, while Dean throws every insult he can at his little brother. He even tries to gaslight Sam into believing he's killing Dean instead of saving him, and points out that Sam is also a monster because of the things he's done trying to save his brother. Things escalate when Dean inevitably breaks free of his restraints and the Devil's Trap. Dean hunts Sam through the bunker, much like Jack hunts his wife in The Shining. Sam, injured and no match for Dean's strength, is forced to move strategically through the bunker, now prey for his older brother to hunt.

Sam and Dean investigate a string of bodies that follow a creepy old painting of a family. According to the stories about the painting, the father killed his entire family and himself. This was so heavily believed that the father was even buried away from the rest of the family. Sam and Dean catch onto the haunted painting as various owners of said painting drop dead in a pool of their own blood. Because of the stories of the family, the brothers believe the ghost of the father is haunting the painting and killing anyone who displays it in their home.

In reality, it turns out that the father in the painting occasionally moves because he's trying to warn people that his youngest daughter is actually responsible for the murders. As a ghost, the killer child is terrifying, but it's even more unsettling to know that, prior to the young girl's death, she slaughtered her entire family. In the Supernatural universe, ghosts will eventually turn vengeful, often doing things they wouldn't normally do in life, but this ghost was a killer prior to her death. This episode proves that evil comes in all shapes and sizes, and even children are capable of horrible things.

"The Benders" is one of the most disturbing episodes in Supernatural because it's one of the first episodes in the series that "breaks" its formula. Up until Season 1, Episode 15, most of the episodes focus on Sam and Dean hunting supernatural creatures, but "The Benders" tells the story of a family of killers. The Benders abduct people a couple of times a year, hold them hostage, and then hunt them for sport. Even the youngest member of the family, a little girl who can't be more than 9 years old, is in on it.

From Sam and Dean Winchester's hilarious quips to Castiel's iconic lines, Supernatural is full of great dialogue.

Sam and Dean are in town to search for the source that causes people to go missing in the local town. They don't find anything supernatural, but Sam is jumped and kidnapped by the Benders. Dean, with the help of a local officer whose brother went missing, tracks Sam to the Benders' where he uncovers the truth about the sadistic family. Real monsters are just ordinary people. That's a lesson Scooby-Doo taught children, and it's a theme that even Supernatural stuck with.

"Skin" is the first time Supernatural introduced the concept of the shapeshifter. According to Supernatural lore, "shifters" are mostly human, but they possess the ability to shed their skin and assume the identity of anyone they come in contact with. In "Skin," Sam and Dean hunt a shapeshifter who has been posing as the significant other of various women. While pretending to be their partner, he slaughters the women brutally, and leaves the real man to take the fall for the crime. The shifter eventually steals Dean's face, but that's not all he gets.

When a shifter takes someone else's skin, the shifter learns everything about that person. So this serial killer shifter essentially becomes Dean Winchester. It's the ultimate form of identity thief and, since most ordinary people don't know that monsters exist, law enforcement has no idea that the killer responsible for so many deaths isn't Dean. "Skin" is the first time one of the Winchesters ends up wanted by the police, but it isn't the last. Between the fear of someone pretending to be someone they aren't, Dean being framed for crimes he didn't commit, and the gnarly way the shifter sheds its skin, this episode is sure to make anyone's skin crawl.

"Family Remains" is another episode that sends Sam and Dean after what they believe to be a monster, but the truth is actually so much worse. Sam and Dean try to stop a family from moving into what they believe to be a haunted house. When the family refuses to listen, they have no choice but to try and protect the family from the vengeful spirit of a young girl. Only, their normal methods of dealing with ghosts, like putting salt circles down, do nothing to stop the ghost in her tracks.

When it comes to hunting things with a tinge of comedy, there's no one better than the Winchester brothers in some of Supernatural's funniest episodes

Sam and Dean eventually uncover that the ghost girl is actually a real, feral girl who has been living within the walls of the house. She was hidden there, never allowed to see the light of day, to cover up her family's horrible, incestuous secret. What Sam and Dean don't know is that the little girl isn't alone. She lives with her older, stronger brother. Together, the siblings kill anyone who enters the house to protect themselves and even potentially eat their victims. The siblings are so hostile and feral, there is no hope to save them, once again proving that humanity is the greatest evil of them all. It's not even that the siblings themselves are monsters, but the family that raised them in such a brutish way surely was.

After Sam and Dean stop the apocalypse by trapping the archangel Michael in the pit with Lucifier, civil war breaks out in Heaven. Castiel and his followers oppose Raphael, who wants to restart the apocalypse. Raphael, however, is an archangel, so he is much more powerful than Castiel. To win the war, Castiel turns to nefarious means, which leads him to partner with Crowley, the King of Hell, to collect as many souls as possible. Both Castiel and Crowley turn their eyes to Purgatory, where millions of souls of untapped potential reside.

Sam and, more importantly, Dean disagree with Castiel's plan to open Purgatory and potentially unleash the monsters that live there. To keep the Winchesters in check, Castiel purposefully breaks the wall in Sam's head put there by Death. After Death retrieved Sam's soul from the pit, he put a wall up in Sam's mind to keep him from remembering his time in Hell or his year without a soul, therefore protecting him from memories that would otherwise destroy him. Castiel breaking Sam's mental wall puts Sam in a catatonic state and has devastating repercussions throughout the next season. This betrayal of one of the Winchesters' closest friends and allies was heartbreaking to watch.

"Hell House" is the first episode where Sam and Dean cross paths with the Ghostfacers, an in-universe Ghost Hunters parody. Sam and Dean are investigating what they believe to be a typical haunted house, but as they investigate, they find the ghost is constantly changing its patterns. Spirits don't typically do that. They're very rigid with where they haunt, how they haunt, and how they kill, so a ghost that changes its methods with every encounter leaves the brothers stumped.

Supernatural's "Swan Song" is hailed as Eric Kripke's perfect finale to the series, but his ending is actually much darker and unsatisfying.

Eventually, they discover they aren't dealing with a ghost, but with a Tulpa. Tulpas are entities that are created purely based on the power of belief. The more people that believe in the Tulpa, the more real the Tulpa becomes. As the story about Hell House's spirit changes and people believe in a new version of the story, the Tulpa's behavior and patterns also shift to match that story. Sam makes a comment about wondering how many monsters they fought existed just because someone believed in them, which is an absolutely terrifying prospect. An idea is powerful enough to create a serial killing ghost, and it doesn't get much darker than that.

Sam and Dean learn that they're the true vessels for Lucifer and Michael, two archangels that are destined to battle and bring on the apocalypse. For most of Season 5, they remain determined to refuse the angels access to their bodies, but eventually, they realize that Lucifer and Michael will destroy the world with or without them. Sam says yes to Lucifer, believing that he can keep control long enough to throw himself into the pit, therefore locking himself and Lucifer in the cage deep within the pits of Hell.

Sam's plan succeeds, and the Winchesters stop the apocalypse, but it forces Dean to live with the reality that his baby brother will be trapped in Hell with the devil for eternity. With the apocalypse subverted and Sam trapped in Hell to suffer forever, it seemed like there was little left for Supernatural to explore. Instead of leaving Sam in Hell, however, the series pulled Sam out of Hell without his soul, which turned him into an incredible hunter, but a ruthless one who would sacrifice people without a second thought.

After Sam's first death at the end of Season 2, Dean makes a deal with a crossroads demon to bring Sam back to life. Most crossroads deals are 10 years. The person who makes the deal gets whatever they want and then, in 10 years' time, the demon comes to collect their soul. Because the Winchesters are a huge problem for demons, the crossroads demon refuses Dean's deal, but eventually agrees, promising to only give Dean one year of life with his brother.

For most of Season 3, Sam is trying to figure out how to save Dean from his deal, while Dean pretends he's made peace with dying. Everyone thought the Winchesters would get Dean out of his deal, but the Season 3 finale actually committed to slaughtering Dean. Dean was sent to Hell, where he was strung up on the rack to be tortured for all eternity. Dean screams for Sam, afraid and desperate, but in Hell, Sam can't reach him. This was one of the most horrifying moments of Supernatural. Many fans wondered if Dean's fate was sealed forever, but fortunately, Castiel makes his series debut by saving Dean from Hell in Season 4.

Title: Russian conspiracy theories and doomed tax avoidance
Description:
This is a weird one.

The "Offshore Advisory Group" publishes political commentary including conspiracy theories originating in Russian propaganda outlets. It uses the attention this attracts to sell a tax avoidance scheme that supposedly lets UK  businesses escape UK tax by incorporating in Gibraltar. The scheme is hopeless and will trigger large taxes and penalties - and if not disclosed could be criminal tax evasion.

Title: 'Criminally overlooked' Netflix series watched for almost 100 million hours is perfect for fans of 91% rated Archer
Description:
Home> Film & TV> Netflix

Ellie Kemp

Netflix subscribers are recommending a 'criminally overlooked' TV series with a near-perfect Rotten Tomatoes score.

First releasing in 2021, the two-part series managed to garner 96.7 million hours in just two years, as per figures from Flixpatrol.

With so many new titles joining Netflix, it can be a little overwhelming to chose your next binge-watch.

Advert

And even if something's previously pulled in big numbers, it may still have slipped under your radar.

If you enjoyed all 14 seasons of adult animation Archer, too, then this TV series should be next on your watch-list.

The animated sci-fi is set in the US - Washington D.C, to be exact.

It centers on Cognito, Inc., a clandestine 'Deep State' organization that employs a team of misfit specialists to manage and conceal real-world conspiracy theories - from reptilian shapeshifters to the Moon landing cover-up.

Advert

While delving into the world of the weird and wonderful, they must also balance their own personal issues as well as the never-ending slog of corporate politics.

Former Gravity Falls writer Shion Takeuchi is the brains behind the show, while Bojack Horseman's Mike Hollingsworth and Gravity Falls' Alex Hirsch serve as executive co-producers.

Lizzy Caplan, Christian Slater, Clark Duke, Tisha Campbell and Andy Daly all lend their voices for the 'binge-worthy' series.

Advert

The show in question is called Inside Job, if you hadn't already guessed.

Racking up an impressive 91 percent Rotten Tomatoes score from fans, the series premiered in two halves; Part 1 landed in October 2021, while Part 2 concluded the season in November 2022.

Fans on the site hailed the show 'binge-worthy,' as one described it 'hands down one of the greatest cartoons Netflix has released.

Over on Reddit, one subscriber was after 'hidden gem' series to get stuck into.

Advert

Among the suggestions was Inside Job, with the first person to recommend it describing it as an 'animated show that basically roasts every conspiracy theory while somehow building a heartwarming ensemble.'

"Criminally overlooked," they added - and others were quick to agree.

"Sucks that it wasn't renewed," one person said, "Theme song was a banger too."

Advert

"For people that loved Archer, this is indeed a gem," a second agreed.

"This show is hilarious and includes every single conspiracy theory," a third said.

A fourth gave their verdict: "This, OP. It became a sleeping comfort show for me after the 2nd watch-through. Ticks all the boxes."

Both parts of Inside Job are available to stream now on Netflix.

Topics: Netflix, Rotten Tomatoes, Conspiracy Theories, Streaming

Title: Putin Expands Secrecy Law to Tighten Wartime Control in Russia
Description:

Americas+1 212 318 2000

The Kremlin has cracked down hard on dissent since Putin ordered the February 2022 invasion of Ukraine.

Source: Bloomberg

President Vladimir Putin has expanded the range of information covered by Russia's state secrecy law, further tightening his grip on society as his war in Ukraine continues.

Details of Russia's foreign policy, international trade and economic policy, scientific developments and preparations for possible military mobilization may all now be classified as secret if disclosure is considered to harm national security, according to a decree published on the government's legal website. Anyone receiving such material in an unauthorized way could face as much as eight years in prison.

Title: Trump says Mamdani must 'do the right thing' if elected mayor of New York City — or risk losing funding
Description:
President Donald Trump said that Democratic candidate Zohran Mamdani has "to do the right thing" if he is elected mayor of New York City, or he could see federal funding dry up.

"Let's say this, if he does get in, I'm going to be president and he's going to have to do the right thing, or they're not getting any money," Trump told Fox News' Maria Bartiromo during an interview that aired Sunday.

"He's got to do the right thing," Trump said.

It's not the first time that Trump has threatened to withhold federal funding for local politicians, particularly those in blue states, whose positions he opposes.

He's previously threatened to strip federal funding from California over Gov. Gavin Newsom's policies towards transgender athletes participating in women's sports.

While Trump took particular aim at Mamdani, the 33-year-old who defeated former New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo in the first round of the city's Democratic mayoral primary last week, he also made a wider funding threat to all New York City mayoral candidates.

"I can tell you this, whoever's mayor of New York is going to have to behave themselves, or the federal government is coming down very tough on them financially," Trump told Bartiromo.

Trump has repeatedly called Mamdani — who is a Democratic socialist — a communist, as he did during the interview on Fox News' Sunday Morning Futures.

Mamdani has rejected that label.

"I am not and I have already had to start to get used to the fact that the president will talk about how I look, how I sound, where I'm from, who I am," Mamdani told NBC News' Kristen Welker on "Meet the Press."

Title: Zelensky signs decree to withdraw from Ottawa Convention banning anti-personnel mines
Description:
President Volodymyr Zelensky signed a decree to withdraw from the Ottawa Convention banning anti-personnel mines, a step that follows the Baltic nations and Poland's move to boost their defense as the war rages on in Ukraine. 

The 1997 treaty, joined by over 160 countries, bans the use, production, stockpiling, and transfer of anti-personnel landmines in efforts to protect civilians from the scattered explosives that could still injure them long after the conflict is over. 

"Russia has never been a party to this convention and uses anti-personnel mines extremely cynically," Zelensky said in justifying the decision. "And not only now, in the war against Ukraine. This is the signature style of Russian killers — to destroy life by all methods at their disposal.

Earlier in March, the Baltic states and Poland announced their intention to withdraw from the Ottawa Convention, a significant shift in defense policy that shows how countries near Ukraine are preparing for a potential war in Europe.

Anti-personnel mines are scattered across the battlefield in Ukraine, with soldiers and civilians often losing their feet or limbs due to detonations. Territories liberated by Ukraine since 2022 have been heavily covered with mines, making it extremely difficult and dangerous to clear them. Russia has used more than a dozen variants of anti-personnel mines since it launched a full-scale invasion of Ukraine in 2022, according to Human Rights Watch's June report. 

In a surprise move that angered Moscow, the Biden administration in 2024 approved the provision of anti-personnel mines to Ukraine. Then Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin said it was to help Ukraine stall the Russian advances in the east as the front-line situation deteriorated.

"This is a step that the reality of war has long demanded," lawmaker Roman Kostenko, secretary of the parliament's defense committee, said in the Facebook post announcing a significant move forward in withdrawing from the major mine treaty. 

Now that Zelensky signed the decree enacting the decision of the National Security and Defense Council of Ukraine, it will land on the parliament's table, Kostenko said. The dates when the decision will take effect are still unclear.
